citation.article-title: Mycobacterium kyorinense sp. nov., a novel, slow-growing species, related to Mycobacterium celatum, isolated from human clinical specimens.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Mycobacterium kyorinense sp. nov.
Mycobacterium kyorinense (kyo.rin.en′se. N.L. neut. adj. kyorinense of Kyorin, referring to the Kyorin University Hospital where the first strain was isolated).
Colony diameters are 1–2 mm on Middlebrook 7H11-OADC agar.
Colonies on 1 % Ogawa egg agar are smooth and raised with round or lobate regular margins, and non-chromogenic.

Negative for Tween hydrolysis, nitrate reductase, semiquantitative catalase, urease activity, 3-day arylsulfatase activity, pyrazinamidase, tellurite reduction and niacin accumulation; positive for 14-day arylsulfatase activity and heat-stable catalase tests.
Susceptible to clarithromycin and ethambutol, but resistant to isoniazid and rifampicin.
Sequence analysis of the 16S rRNA, hsp65, rpoB and sodA genes indicated that M. kyorinense is a mycobacterial species most closely related to M. celatum and M. branderi.

DNA–DNA hybridization revealed that M. kyorinense exhibits DNA similarity values below the suggested threshold with its phylogenetic neighbours M. celatum ATCC 51131T, M. branderi ATCC 51789T and M. branderi ATCC 51788 (similarity 49.9, 44.5 and 41.5 %, respectively), thus defining it as a distinct species. M. kyorinense was placed in the slow-growing mycobacteria group.
The type strain is KUM 060204T (=JCM 15038T=DSM 45166T), isolated from sputum in a patient with pneumonia.
